questions.question: A tax credit differs from a tax deduction because a credit:

options.B: Directly reduces tax liability dollar-for-dollar
options.C: Is only available to high-income taxpayers

questions.explanation: A tax credit directly reduces tax liability dollar-for-dollar, while a deduction only reduces taxable income. A $1,000 credit saves $1,000 in taxes, while a $1,000 deduction saves only $1,000 × the taxpayer's marginal tax rate.
questions.tip: Credit = dollar-for-dollar tax reduction. Deduction = reduces income (saves tax rate × deduction).

questions.question: A refundable tax credit:

options.A: Can only reduce tax to zero
options.B: Can result in a refund even if it exceeds the tax liability
options.C: Is never available to low-income taxpayers
options.D: Must be repaid in future years

questions.explanation: A refundable credit can reduce tax below zero, resulting in a refund to the taxpayer. Nonrefundable credits can only reduce tax liability to zero—any excess is lost (unless carryover is allowed). Refundable credits include EITC and part of the Child Tax Credit.
questions.tip: Refundable = get money back even if no tax owed. Nonrefundable = reduces tax to zero max.

questions.question: The Child Tax Credit for 2023 is:

options.B: $2,000 per qualifying child under age 17

questions.explanation: For 2023, the Child Tax Credit is $2,000 per qualifying child under age 17 at the end of the tax year. Up to $1,600 is refundable as the Additional Child Tax Credit. The enhanced amounts from 2021 have expired.
questions.tip: 2023 Child Tax Credit: $2,000/child under 17. Up to $1,600 refundable.

questions.question: The Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is:

options.A: A nonrefundable credit for all workers
options.B: A refundable credit for low-to-moderate income workers
options.C: Available only to taxpayers with children

questions.explanation: The EITC is a refundable credit for low-to-moderate income workers. The credit amount depends on earned income, AGI, filing status, and number of qualifying children. Taxpayers without children may qualify for a smaller credit.
questions.tip: EITC = refundable, based on earned income. Larger credit with more qualifying children.

questions.question: The Child and Dependent Care Credit applies to expenses for care that enables the taxpayer to:

options.B: Work or look for work

questions.explanation: The Child and Dependent Care Credit is available for expenses paid for care of qualifying individuals (children under 13 or disabled dependents) that enable the taxpayer to work or actively look for work. Both spouses must have earned income (with some exceptions).
questions.tip: Care credit = expenses to enable work. Both spouses need earned income.

questions.question: The American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC) maximum credit is:
questions.explanation: The AOTC provides a maximum credit of $2,500 per eligible student (100% of first $2,000 + 25% of next $2,000 in qualified expenses). It is available for the first four years of post-secondary education, and 40% ($1,000 max) is refundable.
questions.tip: AOTC: max $2,500/student. 40% ($1,000) refundable. First 4 years only.

questions.question: The Lifetime Learning Credit differs from the AOTC in that it:

options.B: Has no limit on the number of years it can be claimed

questions.explanation: The Lifetime Learning Credit (20% of up to $10,000 = $2,000 max) can be claimed for unlimited years, for any post-secondary education (including graduate school), and for courses to acquire or improve job skills. Unlike AOTC, it is nonrefundable and per-taxpayer rather than per-student.
questions.tip: LLC: unlimited years, any education level, $2,000 max per return, nonrefundable.

questions.question: The Retirement Savings Contribution Credit (Saver's Credit) is available to:

options.A: All taxpayers who contribute to retirement accounts
options.B: Low-to-moderate income taxpayers who contribute to qualified retirement plans

questions.explanation: The Saver's Credit provides a nonrefundable credit of 10%-50% (depending on AGI) of retirement contributions up to $2,000 ($4,000 MFJ) for low-to-moderate income taxpayers. AGI limits are relatively low ($73,000 MFJ for 2023).
questions.tip: Saver's Credit: 10-50% of retirement contributions, low-income only, nonrefundable.

questions.question: The foreign tax credit is limited to:

options.B: The U.S. tax attributable to foreign source income

questions.explanation: The foreign tax credit is limited to the amount of U.S. tax attributable to foreign source income. The limitation is calculated as: (Foreign source taxable income / Total taxable income) × U.S. tax liability. Excess credits may be carried back 1 year and forward 10 years.
questions.tip: FTC limited to U.S. tax on foreign income. Prevents double non-taxation.

questions.question: The Adoption Credit for 2023 allows a maximum credit of approximately:
questions.explanation: The Adoption Credit for 2023 allows a credit of up to $15,950 per eligible child for qualified adoption expenses. The credit is nonrefundable but can be carried forward for 5 years. Income phase-outs apply.
questions.tip: Adoption Credit: ~$15,950 max (2023), nonrefundable, 5-year carryforward.

questions.question: The Residential Clean Energy Credit (formerly solar credit) for 2023 provides a credit equal to:

options.A: 10% of the cost of qualified property
options.B: 22% of the cost of qualified property
options.C: 26% of the cost of qualified property
options.D: 30% of the cost of qualified property

questions.explanation: The Inflation Reduction Act restored the residential clean energy credit to 30% for property placed in service from 2022-2032. The credit applies to solar, wind, geothermal, and battery storage systems. It is nonrefundable but can be carried forward.
questions.tip: Residential Clean Energy Credit: 30% through 2032. Solar, wind, geothermal, batteries.

questions.question: The Premium Tax Credit (ACA subsidy) is available to taxpayers who:

options.A: Purchase health insurance through any source
options.B: Purchase coverage through a Health Insurance Marketplace and meet income requirements

questions.explanation: The Premium Tax Credit helps eligible individuals and families afford health insurance purchased through a Health Insurance Marketplace. Income must generally be between 100% and 400% of the federal poverty line (expanded during some years).
questions.tip: Premium Tax Credit: Marketplace insurance only, income-based, refundable.

questions.question: The Credit for Other Dependents provides up to:

options.A: $500 for dependents who don't qualify for the Child Tax Credit
options.B: $1,000 for any dependent

questions.explanation: The Credit for Other Dependents provides a $500 nonrefundable credit for dependents who don't qualify for the $2,000 Child Tax Credit (children 17 and older, qualifying relatives, etc.). It has the same income phase-out thresholds as the Child Tax Credit.
questions.tip: $500 credit for non-CTC dependents (age 17+, qualifying relatives). Nonrefundable.

questions.question: The Credit for the Elderly or Disabled is available to taxpayers who are:

options.B: Age 65 or older, or permanently and totally disabled with taxable disability income
options.C: Any age if they receive Social Security

questions.explanation: The Credit for the Elderly or Disabled is available to taxpayers age 65 or older, or those under 65 who are permanently and totally disabled and have taxable disability income. Low income limits make the credit available primarily to low-income taxpayers.
questions.tip: Elderly/Disabled Credit: 65+ OR disabled with disability income. Very low income limits.

questions.question: Under the Inflation Reduction Act, the clean vehicle credit for new EVs is:

options.B: Up to $7,500 based on battery and assembly requirements

questions.explanation: The IRA provides a credit up to $7,500 for new clean vehicles meeting critical mineral ($3,750) and battery component ($3,750) requirements. There are MSRP caps ($55,000 cars, $80,000 trucks/SUVs) and income limits. The credit is now available at point of sale.
questions.tip: EV credit: up to $7,500, based on battery/mineral sourcing. Price and income caps apply.

questions.question: The Child Tax Credit begins to phase out at modified AGI of:
questions.explanation: The $2,000 Child Tax Credit phases out by $50 for each $1,000 (or fraction) of modified AGI above $200,000 (single, HoH) or $400,000 (MFJ). These thresholds are significantly higher than for other credits, making it available to most middle-class families.
questions.tip: CTC phase-out: $200K single, $400K MFJ. High thresholds—most families qualify.

questions.question: The Earned Income Tax Credit amount:

options.A: Is a flat amount regardless of income
options.B: Increases with income, plateaus, then phases out
options.D: Is the same for all taxpayers

questions.explanation: The EITC has three phases: (1) phase-in where the credit increases with earned income, (2) plateau where the credit remains at maximum, and (3) phase-out where the credit decreases as income rises until eliminated. The credit amount and ranges depend on number of qualifying children.
questions.tip: EITC: phase-in (rises), plateau (max credit), phase-out (falls to zero).

questions.question: The Child and Dependent Care Credit is calculated on expenses up to:

options.A: $2,000 for one qualifying individual, $4,000 for two or more
options.B: $3,000 for one qualifying individual, $6,000 for two or more
options.C: $5,000 for one qualifying individual, $10,000 for two or more
options.D: $8,000 for one qualifying individual, $16,000 for two or more

questions.explanation: The Child and Dependent Care Credit is calculated on expenses up to $3,000 for one qualifying individual or $6,000 for two or more. The credit rate ranges from 20% to 35% based on AGI, resulting in a maximum credit of $600-$1,050 (one) or $1,200-$2,100 (two+).
questions.tip: Care credit: $3K/one, $6K/two+ in expenses. Credit = 20-35% of expenses.

questions.question: The Energy Efficient Home Improvement Credit (formerly nonbusiness energy property credit) under IRA provides:

options.B: An annual credit up to $3,200 for qualifying improvements
options.C: A credit only for new home construction
options.D: A 10% credit with no dollar limit

questions.explanation: IRA enhanced this credit to 30% of costs with annual limits (not lifetime): $1,200 general cap with sub-limits per item type, plus $2,000 for heat pumps. Qualifying improvements include insulation, windows, doors, and efficient HVAC systems.
questions.tip: Home efficiency credit (IRA): 30%, annual $1,200 cap + $2,000 for heat pumps.

questions.question: The federal first-time homebuyer credit:

options.A: Is currently available for all first-time buyers
options.B: Expired and is generally no longer available for purchases after 2010

questions.explanation: The federal first-time homebuyer credit was available for homes purchased in 2008-2010 and has expired. The 2008 credit was essentially a loan that had to be repaid; the 2009-2010 credit did not require repayment unless the home was sold within 3 years.
questions.tip: Federal first-time homebuyer credit: EXPIRED (was 2008-2010 only).

questions.question: The General Business Credit is:

options.A: A single credit calculated on business income
options.B: A combination of multiple business-related tax credits
options.D: A refundable credit for all businesses

questions.explanation: The General Business Credit is an umbrella combining multiple credits (investment credit, work opportunity credit, research credit, small employer health insurance credit, etc.). It is limited to net income tax minus the greater of tentative minimum tax or 25% of net regular tax above $25,000.
questions.tip: General Business Credit = collection of many credits, limited by tax liability formula.

questions.question: The Work Opportunity Tax Credit (WOTC) is available to employers who hire:

options.B: Individuals from targeted groups facing barriers to employment
options.D: Workers who relocate for the job

questions.explanation: WOTC provides a credit for hiring individuals from targeted groups including veterans, ex-felons, long-term unemployed, SNAP recipients, SSI recipients, and others facing employment barriers. The credit is generally 40% of first-year wages up to $6,000.
questions.tip: WOTC: 40% of wages ($6K max) for hiring targeted group members. Must certify.

questions.question: The Research and Experimentation Credit (R&D credit) is calculated using:

options.A: A flat percentage of all research expenses
options.B: Regular credit method or alternative simplified credit method

questions.explanation: The R&D credit can be calculated using the regular credit method (20% of qualified research expenses exceeding a base amount) or the Alternative Simplified Credit (14% of qualified expenses exceeding 50% of average qualified expenses for prior 3 years).
questions.tip: R&D credit: regular method (20%) or ASC (14% of excess). Must be qualified research.

questions.question: The Rehabilitation Tax Credit for certified historic structures is:

options.B: 20% of qualified rehabilitation expenditures, claimed over 5 years

questions.explanation: The Rehabilitation Tax Credit for certified historic structures is 20% of qualified rehabilitation expenditures. TCJA requires the credit to be claimed ratably over 5 years beginning in the year the building is placed in service. The 10% credit for pre-1936 buildings was repealed.
questions.tip: Historic rehab credit: 20%, spread over 5 years. Must be certified historic structure.

questions.question: The prior year minimum tax credit allows taxpayers to:

options.A: Claim AMT paid in prior years against regular tax liability
options.B: Reduce current year AMT
options.C: Carry back AMT to prior years

questions.explanation: When a taxpayer pays AMT due to timing differences (deferral preferences like ISO exercises), they generate an AMT credit that can offset regular tax in future years when the timing reverses. The credit is nonrefundable and carries forward indefinitely.
questions.tip: AMT credit: recover prior AMT from timing items against future regular tax.

questions.question: The Low-Income Housing Tax Credit (LIHTC) provides:

options.A: A one-time credit when housing is constructed
options.B: Annual credits over 10 years for qualified low-income housing projects
options.C: A credit only for individual homeowners
options.D: A credit for renovating personal residences

questions.explanation: LIHTC provides annual credits claimed over 10 years for developing qualified low-income rental housing. Credits are allocated by state housing agencies. The 9% credit applies to new construction; the 4% credit applies to acquisition and rehabilitation.
questions.tip: LIHTC: 10 years of credits. 9% for new construction, 4% for acquisition/rehab.

questions.question: For 2023, EITC eligibility requires investment income to be no more than approximately:

options.D: There is no investment income limit

questions.explanation: For 2023, taxpayers with investment income exceeding $11,000 are ineligible for EITC. Investment income includes interest, dividends, capital gains, and other passive income. This limit was increased from $3,650 under the American Rescue Plan Act.
questions.tip: EITC disqualified if investment income >$11,000 (2023). Higher than old $3,650 limit.

questions.question: To claim education credits, the taxpayer must receive which form from the educational institution?

options.B: Form 1098-T

questions.explanation: Educational institutions issue Form 1098-T reporting amounts billed or paid for qualified tuition and related expenses. Taxpayers use this information to complete Form 8863 to claim the American Opportunity or Lifetime Learning Credit.
questions.tip: 1098-T = tuition statement for education credits. 1098-E = student loan interest.

questions.question: Under the Inflation Reduction Act, the used clean vehicle credit provides:

options.A: Up to $7,500 for any used EV
options.B: Up to $4,000 or 30% of sale price, whichever is less, for qualifying used EVs

questions.explanation: IRA created a new credit for used clean vehicles: the lesser of $4,000 or 30% of the sale price. The vehicle must be at least 2 years old, priced at $25,000 or less, and purchased from a dealer. Income limits apply ($75,000 single, $150,000 MFJ).
questions.tip: Used EV credit: 30% or $4,000 max, price ≤$25K, income limits apply.

questions.question: Employers providing qualified childcare facilities can claim a credit of:

options.B: 25% of qualified childcare facility expenses plus 10% of referral expenses, up to $150,000

questions.explanation: The employer-provided childcare credit is 25% of qualified childcare facility expenditures plus 10% of qualified childcare resource and referral expenditures, with a maximum credit of $150,000. Basis of the facility must be reduced by the credit amount.
questions.tip: Employer childcare credit: 25% facility + 10% referral costs, max $150K.

questions.question: The small employer health insurance credit is available to employers with:

options.B: Fewer than 25 full-time equivalent employees with average wages below $58,000 (2023)

questions.explanation: The small employer health insurance credit (up to 50% of premiums, 35% for tax-exempt employers) requires: fewer than 25 FTEs, average annual wages below ~$58,000, employer pays at least 50% of premiums, and coverage purchased through SHOP marketplace.
questions.tip: Small employer health credit: <25 FTEs, low average wages, 50%+ premium contribution.

questions.question: The Disabled Access Credit for small businesses provides:

options.B: 50% of eligible access expenditures between $250 and $10,250, for a maximum credit of $5,000

questions.explanation: The Disabled Access Credit provides 50% of eligible expenditures between $250 and $10,250 (maximum credit $5,000) for small businesses making their facilities accessible to disabled individuals. The business must have gross receipts ≤$1M or ≤30 FTEs.
questions.tip: Disabled access credit: 50% of costs $250-$10,250 = max $5,000. Small business only.

questions.question: When a taxpayer has multiple credits, they are generally applied in which order?

options.B: Nonrefundable credits first, then refundable credits
options.D: The taxpayer may choose the order

questions.explanation: Nonrefundable credits are applied first to reduce tax liability to zero, then refundable credits are applied (which can result in a refund). This ordering maximizes benefit because refundable credits can generate refunds while nonrefundable credits cannot.
questions.tip: Order: nonrefundable credits first (to zero), then refundable (can get money back).

questions.question: The investment tax credit (including energy credits) may be subject to recapture if:

options.B: The property is disposed of or ceases to be qualified property within 5 years
options.C: The taxpayer moves to a different state

questions.explanation: Investment tax credits are subject to recapture if the property is disposed of or ceases to be qualified property within 5 years of being placed in service. The recapture percentage decreases by 20% for each full year the property was held.
questions.tip: ITC recapture: if disposed within 5 years, pay back portion based on holding period.

questions.question: The employer credit for paid family and medical leave (Section 45S) provides:

options.A: A credit equal to 100% of wages paid during leave
options.B: A credit of 12.5% to 25% of wages paid for qualifying leave
options.D: A credit only for large employers

questions.explanation: Section 45S provides a credit for employers who provide paid family and medical leave. The credit is 12.5% of wages paid if the payment rate is 50% of normal wages, increasing by 0.25% for each percentage point above 50%, up to 25% if paying 100% of wages.
questions.tip: Paid leave credit: 12.5% base (at 50% pay), up to 25% (at 100% pay).
